childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 2006-2018

You arrived the year Twitter launched with 140 characters and Pluto lost its planetary status. Both events are strangely relevant to your generation's relationship with brevity and existential demotion. Jack Dorsey's first tweet—'just setting up my twttr'—would become a cultural artifact worth millions. Meanwhile, astronomers decided Pluto wasn't a planet after all, teaching an entire generation that facts could change when enough experts decided to vote differently.

George W. Bush was in the White House, still processing the Iraq War that kept dragging on. Hurricane Katrina was fresh in national memory. The iPhone didn't exist yet—you'd have to wait a whole year for that. Your birth year was the last moment when smartphones weren't the default interface between humans and reality.

Your childhood included stretches where adults seemed stressed about money more than seemed normal. You were too young to understand the specifics, but you absorbed the atmosphere—budget conversations, 'we can't afford that' becoming a phrase you heard regularly, a sense that prosperity required careful management. That became your baseline for how finances worked.

Technology-wise, you never knew a world without YouTube. It launched just a year before you were born. By the time you were watching screens, streaming was already the default. You probably had an iPad before you had shoelaces you could tie yourself. Touchscreens felt intuitive because you literally grew up touching them before you could read.

You were seven during Sandy Hook. You don't remember a time before school shooting drills. Lockdowns weren't new or scary additions—they were just how school worked. The anxiety of that became background noise, something you learned to live with because the alternative was too big to process and nobody was fixing it.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen Z

You're Gen Z, born between 1997 and 2012. That's the Pew Research definition, which means you're right in the middle of your generation—not the elder Gen Z who remembers flip phones, not the youngest who seem more like Gen Alpha. You're the generation born into the aftermath of 9/11—too young to remember the towers falling, old enough to inherit the surveillance state, the forever wars, and the ambient anxiety they created. You're the median. The quintessential Gen Z experience is your experience.

You're the most racially and ethnically diverse generation in American history, with nearly half identifying as non-white. You're also the most educated and the most connected. These aren't just statistics—they shape how you see the world and how the world markets to you.

There's no single defining moment for Gen Z the way 9/11 was for Millennials. Instead, you have a constellation of traumas: school shootings that blur together in memory, climate anxiety that started in elementary school, a pandemic that ate your adolescence. Your defining characteristic isn't a single event—it's perpetual crisis as a baseline expectation.

You didn't adopt social media—you were raised by it, shaped by it, formed in its image. You never expected the system to work for you. Millennials believed in institutions and were betrayed by them. You watched that betrayal and took notes. You're not disillusioned because you were never illusioned in the first place. That's either pragmatism or learned helplessness, depending on who you ask. You're not cynical—you're realistic. Stability was a concept other generations experienced; you just read about it.

You're the first generation to grow up entirely in the smartphone era without any memory of what came before. You don't remember a time when you couldn't reach anyone instantly. Privacy is a concept you understand intellectually but have never actually experienced. Your childhood photos were posted to Facebook before you could consent. Your digital footprint started before you could walk.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year The Departed won Best Picture and Martin Scorsese finally got his Oscar after decades of snubs. Cars became Pixar's latest hit and launched a franchise that would sell billions in merchandise. High School Musical premiered on Disney Channel—a movie that would define the aesthetic of your early childhood even if you were too young to watch it in real-time. Daniel Craig became the new James Bond. 'Bad Day' by Daniel Powter was inescapable.

Musically, 2006 was peak mid-2000s pop-punk and emo. My Chemical Romance released The Black Parade and taught teenagers that death could be theatrical. Fall Out Boy, Panic! at the Disco, and Paramore were unavoidable on the radio. This was music your older siblings and babysitters played, and it seeped into your consciousness. You'd rediscover it ironically in high school and then unironically love it.

TV in your childhood meant Nickelodeon and Disney Channel original programming. iCarly taught you that anyone with a webcam could become famous. Hannah Montana tackled fame's costs before you understood what fame cost. Drake & Josh, SpongeBob, Avatar: The Last Airbender. You grew up with content designed specifically for you, algorithmically optimized for engagement before you knew what algorithms were.

Your tween years collided with the rise of YouTube creators who became more famous than traditional celebrities. You probably watched more PewDiePie, Smosh, and Markiplier than traditional TV shows. By high school, TikTok arrived and rewired your attention span entirely. You consume content in fifteen-second clips. Anything longer feels like a commitment requiring justification.

The Marvel Cinematic Universe spans your entire conscious life. Iron Man came out when you were two. You've never known a world without superhero movies dominating the box office. Endgame happened when you were thirteen, which felt like the end of something important.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Twitter launched with Jack Dorsey's first tweet, though the platform wouldn't matter to you for years. Google bought YouTube for $1.65 billion, which seemed insane at the time and looks like a bargain now. The Nintendo Wii brought motion controls to gaming, and your family probably had one in the living room by the time you were old enough to hold a controller.

You were one year old when the iPhone launched. You don't remember the world before smartphones because you literally couldn't form memories yet. By the time you were aware of technology, touchscreens were just how things worked. The idea of a phone with physical buttons seems quaint to you, like rotary dials or telegraphs.

You were four when the iPad came out and changed how children interact with media. You probably learned to swipe before you learned to write cursive—if you learned cursive at all. Your elementary school might have had iPads in the classroom. Your babysitter probably handed you one to keep you quiet on long car rides.

You were six when Instagram launched. Ten when Snapchat went mainstream. Fourteen when TikTok took over everything. Your social media evolution wasn't Facebook to Instagram to TikTok. It was Instagram to Snapchat to TikTok, with Facebook being something your parents and grandparents use.

COVID hit when you were thirteen or fourteen, right in the middle of high school. School went online. Socialization became Zoom calls and Discord servers. You learned that 'hybrid learning' meant nobody was learning anything well. The technology that was supposed to connect you made you feel more isolated than ever.

Your relationship with technology is complicated in ways older generations don't fully understand. You know it's bad for you. You know it's designed to be addictive. You use it anyway because the alternative is being disconnected from everyone you know. That's not a choice—it's a hostage situation.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born five years after the towers fell. You don't remember a world before the War on Terror because there wasn't one during your lifetime. You were {{AGE_AT_IPHONE}} when the iPhone launched, {{AGE_AT_COVID}} when COVID hit. You were born the year Saddam Hussein was executed in Iraq, which you learned about in history class as a thing that happened, not as news you experienced live. The Iraq War was background noise for your entire childhood—something on the news that adults talked about but that didn't directly affect your daily life unless someone in your family was deployed.

The forever wars in Afghanistan and Iraq formed the backdrop of your childhood. You've never known a country not at war somewhere. Peace was a theoretical concept older people described, not something you experienced.

You were five when Osama bin Laden was killed. You probably remember the adults being excited, even if you didn't fully understand why everyone was celebrating someone's death. You were seven when Sandy Hook happened. Twenty first-graders, kids around your age. That was when school started feeling like a place where bad things could happen. Your lockdown drills got more serious.

You were nine when marriage equality became law nationwide. By the time you were thinking about identity and relationships, LGBTQ+ rights were established, not aspirational. This seems obvious to you. It wasn't obvious to anyone who came before you.

You were ten when Donald Trump announced his presidential campaign. Fourteen when the pandemic started. You watched the 2020 election, George Floyd protests, and the January 6th insurrection from whatever device you had. History was happening in real-time on your phone, sandwiched between TikToks and group chat memes.

You were eighteen when—well, we don't know yet. You're living through history right now, and it's probably exhausting. Your generation has experienced more 'unprecedented' events before turning twenty than previous generations experienced in a lifetime.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You're just entering the workforce now, and the landscape is unrecognizable from what career counselors described when you were younger. Traditional career paths—college degree, entry-level job, climb the ladder—feel like advice from another century. The people telling you to 'pound the pavement' and 'get your foot in the door' haven't applied for a job since applications were on paper.

Your generation is pioneering the creator economy not as a side hustle but as a legitimate career path. You know people who make more from TikTok than their parents make at their jobs. You understand that attention is currency, that personal branding isn't optional, that being discoverable online is part of being employable.

You're entering a job market that's been reshaped by COVID. Remote work is normal now. Hybrid schedules are expected. The five-day office week feels like a relic from your parents' generation. But you also know that 'flexible' often means 'available 24/7' and 'work-life balance' is marketing copy, not actual policy.

The game isn't rigged against you specifically—it's just rigged. That's weirdly comforting once you accept it. You've watched Millennials burn out chasing hustle culture and decided that's not going to be your path. Quiet quitting, acting your wage, maintaining boundaries—these aren't laziness. They're survival strategies learned from watching the previous generation sacrifice everything for companies that laid them off via Zoom anyway.

You're entering a job market being actively rewritten by artificial intelligence. The rules are changing faster than anyone can document them. AI is reshaping every industry as you enter the workforce. The skills you're learning might be automated before you're thirty. You're building careers on shifting ground, which isn't new—every generation faces change—but the pace of change is faster than anything before. Adaptability isn't a nice-to-have. It's the only thing that matters. The old path—degree, job, promotion, house, retirement—is dead. You're not following it; you're building something new on its grave.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You've never known dating without apps as the default infrastructure. Tinder launched when you were seven. By the time you were interested in relationships, swiping was just how it worked, as normal as using GPS instead of memorizing directions. The idea of meeting someone organically—at a bookstore, through friends, at a party—sounds romantic but also statistically unlikely.

Your communication is primarily text-based, but it's layered in ways older generations don't fully grasp. You know the difference between a 'haha,' a 'lol,' and a 'lmao.' You know that a period at the end of a text can be passive-aggressive. You communicate through memes, voice notes, and reaction emojis. Actual phone calls feel aggressive and intrusive.

You came of age during the pandemic, which means you missed formative social experiences. Proms were canceled. Graduations were Zoom calls. The parties, the awkward dances, the in-person rejection that teaches you resilience—you didn't get those. You got Animal Crossing and existential dread.

Your generation is dating less, having less sex, and partnering later than any previous generation measured. This isn't prudishness—it's a combination of economic precarity, mental health challenges, and having social needs partially met by online communities. Why risk rejection when you can find connection on Discord?

Friendships for your generation exist across platforms and geography. You have friends you've never met in person who you talk to daily. The distinction between 'online friends' and 'real friends' feels outdated and artificial. Connection is connection. Geography is just logistics.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}} when the 2008 financial crisis hit. You don't remember it consciously, but your household does—and that anxiety became your inheritance. You've never experienced a stable economy in your conscious memory. Financial security isn't a destination for your generation—it's a moving target that keeps receding as you approach. The idea of job security, affordable housing, and straightforward retirement sounds like something from a history book, not a realistic expectation for your twenties.

Your financial worldview is shaped by watching your parents navigate finances carefully, sometimes struggle with things they expected to be easier. You took notes on what worked and what didn't. Gap years, trade schools, skipping college entirely—these aren't failures in your view. They're rational responses to a changing cost-benefit calculation around education.

You're surprisingly financially literate for your age, mostly because you had to be and because TikTok made financial concepts accessible content. Personal finance influencers taught you about investing, budgeting, and side hustles before any adult thought to mention compound interest. You know what index funds are. You understand dollar-cost averaging. Whether you have any money to actually invest is a different question.

Housing costs roughly ten times median income now, compared to three times when your grandparents were buying. Student loan debt averages over $30,000 for bachelor's graduates. Homeownership isn't a milestone for your generation—it's a math problem that doesn't solve. These numbers shape how you think about major life decisions—not as milestones to achieve on a timeline, but as calculations to run carefully.

Crypto, meme stocks, NFTs—you were there for all of it, watching the chaos unfold. You watched people your age make millions and lose everything in the same week. You're skeptical of get-rich-quick schemes, but you also understand that slow-and-steady feels harder when the traditional path seems blocked by prices that have outpaced wages.

You're not irrational actors making poor choices—you're rational actors in an irrational system, making the best decisions available. Your generation isn't lazy about money—you're calculating. You've done the math on homeownership. You've seen retirement calculators and questioned the assumptions. You're not planning for a future that looks exactly like your parents' future. You're planning for something different, whatever that turns out to be.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest weakness is that you've never known anything but crisis, which means you might not recognize when things are actually getting better. Your baseline is so skewed toward pessimism that good news feels like a trap. Optimism seems naive. Hope feels like something that will hurt you if you let it.

You're so terminally online that you sometimes mistake internet consensus for real-world consensus. The discourse on Twitter or TikTok isn't representative of what most people think. The loudest voices aren't the majority. But when you're chronically online, it's hard to remember that most people aren't.

Your generation struggles with sustained attention in ways that might limit what you can accomplish. You're used to content designed to capture you in seconds. Deep work—the kind that requires hours of uninterrupted focus—feels almost physically painful. This isn't a moral failing. It's what happens when your brain is trained by algorithms optimized for engagement over depth.

You can be quick to cancel and slow to forgive. The impulse makes sense—you've watched institutions fail, leaders disappoint, and bad actors escape consequences. Holding people accountable matters. But the binary of canceled/acceptable doesn't leave room for growth, complexity, or context. Sometimes people are wrong without being irredeemable.

You're comfortable with digital activism but less comfortable with the slow, boring work of actual change. Posting is easy. Phone banking is hard. Sharing a petition feels productive. Showing up to a school board meeting doesn't get likes. The dopamine hit of online engagement can substitute for the unsexy grind of real organizing.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your teens (2019-2024): Your teenage years were interrupted by a global pandemic. You spent formative years masked, distanced, and online. You missed milestones that every generation before you took for granted. You're already behind through no fault of your own, and you'll spend your twenties catching up on social skills and experiences that should have happened naturally.

Your 20s (2026-2036): You're entering this decade now, or about to. This is when you'll figure out who you are outside of school, outside of your parents' home, outside of the structures that have defined you so far. The job market is weird. Housing is impossible. Dating is apps. You'll probably change careers multiple times. You'll definitely question everything you were told about how life is supposed to work. That questioning is healthy. The old script doesn't apply.

Your 30s (2036-2046): By now, you'll have established something—a career, a community, maybe a family. Or you'll have deliberately opted out of those things, and that's fine too. You'll be managing the fallout of climate change, which will have stopped being abstract and started being logistical. Where can you afford to live that isn't flooding, burning, or freezing? These will be real questions requiring real answers.

Your 40s (2046-2056): You'll be mid-career, maybe peak career, in an economy that looks nothing like today's. AI will have reshaped work in ways we can't predict from here. You might be managing AI systems. You might be competing with them. You'll be the 'senior' person in rooms full of Gen Alpha and Gen Beta, who will think your references are ancient. You'll be parenting teenagers, if you have kids, and trying to navigate technology that makes TikTok look quaint.

Your 50s and beyond (2056+): Retirement as a concept may not exist by then, or it might look completely different. You'll have lived through multiple 'once-in-a-lifetime' crises before hitting this decade. You'll tell younger people about the pandemic, the political chaos, the climate tipping points. They'll think of it the way you think of the Cold War—something that shaped a generation but feels historical. You'll be adapting, because that's what you've always done. Adaptation isn't a strategy for your generation. It's a survival skill baked in from birth.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly {{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people born in {{BIRTH_YEAR}}. The entire Gen Z population is about 68 million Americans, making you slightly smaller than Millennials but the most diverse generation in American history. Nearly half identify as non-white, compared to 39% of Millennials and 30% of Gen X.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more pragmatic and less idealistic about what institutions can deliver. Millennials believed in institutions and were disappointed by their failures. You never believed in the first place. They graduated into one recession and hoped for better. You're graduating into whatever this is. They remember life before smartphones; you don't. They're burned out from trying; you're burned out preemptively, having watched them sacrifice everything for nothing.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're similar in skepticism but different in context. Gen X was the forgotten middle child between Boomers and Millennials, largely ignored by marketers and researchers. You're the overlooked younger sibling of Millennials, constantly compared to them. Gen X had latchkey childhoods and learned independence through benign neglect. You had helicopter parents and learned anxiety through constant monitoring. They're running things now, for better or worse.

Boomers controlled 21% of the nation's wealth at your age. Your generation controls about 5%. That's not a typo—it's a transfer. Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the wealth gap is almost incomprehensible. They controlled about 21% of the nation's wealth at your age. Your generation controls less than 5%. They grew up when college cost a summer job, houses cost a year's salary, and 'the future' was bright and promising. You grew up when those economics inverted dramatically. The wealth they accumulated is not being passed down equitably. The planet they inherited is not being preserved. You'll spend your life managing the consequences of their choices.

Compared to Gen Alpha (born 2013-2025), you're the experienced older sibling. You remember the transition to smartphones. They don't. You remember the pandemic happening. They'll just know the world after. You're the last generation to remember any version of 'before.' That makes you a bridge—the translators between the analog past and the digital future.

Your life expectancy is projected around 77-79 years, slightly lower than previous generations due to rising deaths of despair, chronic stress, and healthcare costs that make prevention a luxury. You're the most connected generation in history—and statistically the loneliest. Both things are true. Both things are related. Your mental health outcomes show higher rates of anxiety, depression, and suicidal ideation than previous generations at the same age. This isn't weakness—it's what happens when you grow up with constant access to global trauma, comparison through social media, and a future that looks increasingly uncertain. You're coping with more than any generation should have to.

year_events: Nintendo Wii released and sold out everywhere
An Inconvenient Truth made climate change mainstream
